records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.content: This document explains the comprehensive SEO and GEO (Generative Engine Optimization) system implemented in this documentation pipeline.
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Overview
records.content: The scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py is a unified tool that handles all SEO/GEO optimization: - GEO Linting: Optimizes content for LLM extraction and citation - SEO Enhancement: Generates structured data, meta tags, and sitemaps - Search Optimization: Creates Algolia-optimized search records - Metadata Auto-Enhancement: Infers metadata from paths and content
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: 1. GEO (Generative Engine Optimization)
records.content: Optimizes documentation for AI/LLM consumption: - First Paragraph Optimization: Ensures first 60 words contain clear definitions - Heading Quality: Detects generic headings that reduce discoverability - Fact Density: Ensures concrete facts every 200 words - Definition Patterns: Checks for clear "is/enables/provides" patterns - Hierarchy Validation: Ensures proper heading structure
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: 2. SEO Enhancement
records.content: Improves traditional search engine optimization: - Structured Data: Generates JSON-LD schema for rich snippets - Meta Tags: Creates comprehensive Open Graph and Twitter Card tags - Canonical URLs: Manages canonical links for duplicate content - Sitemap Generation: Automated sitemap.xml with priorities - Lifecycle Management: Handles deprecated/preview content
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: 3. Search Optimization
records.content: Optimizes for internal search (Algolia): - Faceted Search: Enables filtering by product, type, component - Ranking Boost: Prioritizes based on content type and freshness - Section Indexing: Breaks documents into searchable chunks - Code Awareness: Indexes code snippets separately
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: 4. Metadata Intelligence
records.content: Automatically infers and enhances metadata: - Path-based Inference: Determines content_type from directory structure - Content Analysis: Detects patterns to identify document type - Git Integration: Adds last_reviewed dates from git history - Tag Generation: Auto-generates relevant tags
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Basic GEO/SEO check
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Fix issues and enhance metadata
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/ --fix
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Generate sitemap
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/ --sitemap
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Generate Algolia records
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/ --algolia
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: All optimizations
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/ --fix --sitemap --algolia
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: GitHub Actions
records.content: The pipeline runs automatically: 1. On PR: Validates SEO/GEO compliance 2. On Push to Main: Updates search index and sitemap 3. Weekly: Full optimization with auto-fixes
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Pre-commit Hook
records.content: Runs automatically before commits:
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Install pre-commit
records.content: pip install pre-commit pre-commit install
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Run manually
records.content: pre-commit run seo-geo-check --all-files
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Required Frontmatter
records.content: Every document must have: --- title: "Clear title under 70 characters" description: "SEO description between 50-160 characters" content_type: tutorial|how-to|concept|reference|troubleshooting ---
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Optional Enhancements
records.content: --- product:-cloud|the product-self-hosted|both app_component: webhook|http-request|code|ai-agent maturity: preview|beta|ga|deprecated|removed tags: [Tag1, Tag2, Tag3] # Max 8 tags last_reviewed: 2024-01-15 ---
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Critical (Blocks PR)
records.content: - Missing required frontmatter fields - Description outside 50-160 character range - Heading hierarchy violations - Invalid content_type values
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Warnings (Should Fix)
records.content: - First paragraph over 60 words - Generic headings (Overview, Setup, etc.) - Low fact density (>200 words without specifics) - Missing definition patterns
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Suggestions (Nice to Have)
records.content: - Add more descriptive headings - Include code examples - Add structured data hints
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Content Maturity States
records.content: 1. preview: New experimental features 2. beta: Testing phase, may change 3. ga: Generally available, stable 4. deprecated: Will be removed, use alternatives 5. removed: No longer available
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Automated Actions
records.content: - deprecated: Lower search ranking, add warning banner - removed: Generate 301 redirect, exclude from search - preview: Add preview badge, monitor duration
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Search Ranking Factors
records.content: Documents are ranked by: 1. Content Type (tutorials > how-tos > reference) 2. Path Depth (shallower = more important) 3. Freshness (recently updated ranks higher) 4. Maturity (GA > beta > preview > deprecated) 5. Fact Density (more code/config = higher value)
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Weekly Reports
records.content: The system generates: - GEO compliance scores - SEO metadata coverage - Search query gaps (from Algolia) - Stale content alerts - Deprecated content tracking
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Metrics Tracked
records.content: - First paragraph word count - Heading descriptiveness score - Fact density ratio - Metadata completeness - Search click-through rate
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: For Maximum LLM Visibility
records.content: 1. Start with a definition: "The Webhook node is..." 2. Use specific headings: "Configure OAuth 2.0" not "Configuration" 3. Include concrete facts: Ports, defaults, limits 4. Provide code examples: Even small snippets help
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: For Search Optimization
records.content: 1. Complete all metadata: Helps with faceted search 2. Use descriptive titles: Include key terms users search 3. Write clear descriptions: 50-160 chars, action-oriented 4. Tag appropriately: Maximum 8 relevant tags
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: For Content Lifecycle
records.content: 1. Mark maturity state: Helps users understand stability 2. Set replacement paths: For deprecated content 3. Update regularly: Keep last_reviewed current 4. Archive properly: Use removed state, not delete
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Common Issues
records.content: Issue: "Description too short" error Fix: Expand to 50+ characters with key terms Issue: "Generic heading" warning Fix: Make heading specific: "Configure webhook authentication" Issue: "Low fact density" Fix: Add numbers, code, configuration values Issue: "No definition pattern" Fix: Start with "X is/enables/provides..."
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Verbose output
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/ --output debug.json
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Dry run (no changes)
records.content: python scripts/seo_geo_optimizer.py docs/ --dry-run
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Algolia
records.content: Records are optimized for: - Faceted search by product/type/component - Smart ranking based on content quality - Section-level search granularity
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: Google Search
records.content: Structured data enables: - Rich snippets in search results - Breadcrumb navigation - FAQ accordions - How-to steps
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: SEO/GEO Optimization Guide
records.heading: AI Assistants
records.content: GEO optimization improves: - Answer extraction accuracy - Citation likelihood - Context understanding - Factual grounding
records.description: Comprehensive guide to SEO and GEO optimization in the documentation pipeline

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Overview
records.content: This documentation system uses Jinja2 templating through mkdocs-macros-plugin to maintain consistency and avoid repetition.
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: In Markdown Files
records.content: Simply use double curly braces: The default port for {{ product_name }} is {{ default_port }}. Visit {{ product_name }} Cloud to get started. Maximum payload size: {{ max_payload_size_mb }}MB
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Conditional Content
records.content: Use Jinja2 conditions for dynamic content: {% if product == "the product-cloud" %}
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Cloud-specific Instructions
records.content: This feature is only available in {{ product_name }} Cloud. {% else %}
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Self-hosted Instructions
records.content: Run on port {{ default_port }} by default. {% endif %}
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Loops for Lists
records.content: {% for var, value in env_vars.items() %} - {{ value }}: Configure {{ var }} {% endfor %}
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Available Variables
records.content: All variables are defined in docs/_variables.yml:
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Product Information
records.content: - {{ product_name }} - - {{ product_full_name }} - workflow automation - {{ current_version }} - Current version number
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: URLs
records.content: - {{ cloud_url }} - Cloud app URL - {{ docs_url }} - Documentation URL - {{ community_url }} - Community forum URL - {{ github_url }} - GitHub repository
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Configuration
records.content: - {{ default_port }} - Default port (5678) - {{ default_webhook_port }} - Webhook port - {{ default_data_folder }} - Data folder path - {{ max_payload_size_mb }} - Max payload size
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Environment Variables
records.content: Access via env_vars dictionary: - {{ env_vars.webhook_url }} - WEBHOOK_URL - {{ env_vars.port }} - APP_PORT - {{ env_vars.data_folder }} - APP_USER_FOLDER
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: 1. Install mkdocs-macros-plugin
records.content: pip install mkdocs-macros-plugin
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: 2. Configure mkdocs.yml
records.content: plugins:  - macros:  include_dir: docs  include_yaml:  - _variables.yml
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: 3. Use in Templates
records.content: All VS Code snippets now include variables: - Type doc-tutorial → includes {{ min_version }} - Type doc-howto → includes {{ default_port }} - Type doc-reference → includes {{ product_name }}
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: 1. Always Use Variables For:
records.content: - Product names - Version numbers - URLs - Port numbers - File paths - Size limits - Timeouts
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: 2. Never Hardcode:
records.content: - URLs (use {{ cloud_url }}, {{ docs_url }}) - Version numbers (use {{ current_version }}) - Configuration values (use variables from _variables.yml)
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: 3. Create New Variables When:
records.content: - You use the same value in 3+ places - The value might change in the future - It's configuration-specific
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Adding New Variables
records.content: 1. Edit docs/_variables.yml:
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Add your variable
records.content: my_new_variable: "value" 2. Use in any markdown file: The value is {{ my_new_variable }}. 3. Variables are available immediately after saving.
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Variable Not Rendering
records.content: Problem: You see {{ variable_name }} in output Solution: Ensure mkdocs-macros-plugin is installed and configured
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Variable Not Found Error
records.content: Problem: Build fails with "variable not defined" Solution: Check variable name in _variables.yml
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Conditional Content Not Working
records.content: Problem: Jinja2 conditions show in output Solution: Use {% raw %} tags to escape if needed: {% raw %} This will show: {{ variable_name }} {% endraw %}
records.description: How to use Jinja2 variables and templates in documentation for consistency

records.title: Variables and Templates Guide
records.heading: Complete Page with Variables
records.content: --- title: "Configure {{ product_name }} Webhooks" description: "Learn how to set up webhooks on port {{ default_webhook_port }}" ---

records.heading: Prerequisites
records.content: - {{ product_name }} version {{ min_supported_version }} or later - Access to port {{ default_webhook_port }}

records.heading: Configuration
records.content: {% if product == "the product-cloud" %} Visit {{ product_name }} Cloud and navigate to Settings. {% else %} Set the environment variable: export {{ env_vars.webhook_url }}=https://your-domain.com:{{ default_webhook_port }} {% endif %}

records.title: Concepts and Architecture
records.heading: Concepts
records.content: Understand how works under the hood. Read these when you need to understand why, not just how.
records.description: Explanations of internals: workflow execution model, data flow, credential management, and security architecture.

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: How the workflow execution model works
records.content: The execution model determines how data flows from one node to the next within a workflow. executes nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects. Understanding this model helps you build reliable workflows and debug unexpected behavior.
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

hierarchy.lvl2: How the workflow execution model works

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: Data structure between nodes
records.content: Every node in receives and outputs data in the same format: an array of items, where each item is a JSON object wrapped in a json key. [  { "json": { "name": "Alice", "email": "alice@example.com" } },  { "json": { "name": "Bob", "email": "bob@example.com" } } ] When a node receives 5 items, it processes each item independently. The Slack node, for example, sends 5 separate messages — one per item.
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: Execution flow
records.content: flowchart LR  A[Trigger] -->|items| B[Node 1]  B -->|transformed items| C[Node 2]  C -->|items| D{IF condition}  D -->|true| E[Branch A]  D -->|false| F[Branch B] follows these rules during execution: 1. The trigger node starts the workflow and produces the initial items. 1. Each subsequent node receives all output items from the previous node. 1. A node processes items either once for all items or once per item, depending on the node type and configuration. 1. Branch nodes (IF, Switch) route items to different paths based on conditions. 1. Execution stops when all branches reach their final nodes.
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: Execution modes
records.content: supports two execution modes that affect error handling and performance. === "Regular mode (default)"  Nodes execute one at a time. If a node fails, execution stops and the workflow reports an error. This mode is predictable and easier to debug.  Set in environment: EXECUTIONS_MODE=regular === "Queue mode (production)"  Workflow executions are distributed across worker processes. This mode handles high-volume workloads (hundreds of concurrent executions) and requires a Redis instance for coordination.  Set in environment: EXECUTIONS_MODE=queue
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: Error handling
records.content: When a node fails, behavior depends on the node's error handling setting: - Stop execution (default): The workflow stops. The error appears in the execution log. - Continue on fail: The node outputs an error object, and the next node receives it. Use this for non-critical steps like logging. - Error Trigger workflow: starts a separate workflow to handle the error. Use this for alerting and retry logic.
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: Key implications for documentation writers
records.content: The execution model means that every node reference page should document what input format the node expects, what output format it produces (how many items, what structure), and how the node behaves with multiple items (once for all vs. once per item).
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

records.title: How the workflow execution model works
records.heading: Related
records.content: - Build your first workflow - Webhook node reference
records.description: processes workflows by executing nodes sequentially, passing data as arrays of JSON objects between each node in the chain.

records.title: Getting Started
records.heading: Getting Started
records.content: Tutorials walk you through from zero to a working automation. Each tutorial produces a concrete result.
records.description: Step-by-step tutorials to help you build your first workflow, from installation through your first automation.

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.content: A workflow is a series of connected nodes that process data automatically. In this tutorial you create a workflow that receives an HTTP request via a Webhook node and sends a notification to Slack.
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

hierarchy.lvl2: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Prerequisites
records.content: - An instance (Cloud or self-hosted). See installation options. - A Slack workspace where you can add apps.
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Step 1: Create a new workflow
records.content: === "Cloud" - Log in to your Cloud instance. - Select New Workflow from the top-right menu. - The canvas opens with an empty workflow. === "Self-hosted" - Open your instance at <http://localhost:5678.> - Select New Workflow. - The canvas opens with an empty workflow.
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Step 2: Add a Webhook trigger node
records.content: 1. Select the + button on the canvas. 1. Search for Webhook and select it. 1. Set HTTP Method to POST. 1. Copy the Test URL — you will need it in Step 5. !!! info "Test URL vs Production URL"  The Test URL is active only while the workflow editor is open. The Production URL activates after you toggle the workflow to Active.
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

hierarchy.lvl2: Step 2: Add a Webhook trigger node

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Step 3: Add a Slack node
records.content: 1. Select the + button after the Webhook node. 1. Search for Slack and select it. 1. Set Operation to Send a Message. 1. Select your Slack credential or create one (requires a Slack Bot Token with chat:write scope). 1. Set Channel to your target channel name or ID. 1. Set Text to an expression: New webhook received: {% raw %}{{ $json.body.message }}{% endraw %}
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Step 4: Test the workflow
records.content: 1. Select Test Workflow in the top bar. 1. In a terminal, send a test request: curl -X POST YOUR_TEST_URL \  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \  -d '{"message": "Hello from my first workflow!"}' 1. Check your Slack channel — the message appears within 2 seconds.
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Step 5: Activate the workflow
records.content: 1. Toggle the workflow to Active in the top-right corner. 1. Replace the Test URL with the Production URL in your application. The workflow now runs automatically for every incoming request, without the editor open.
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

records.title: Build your first workflow in 5 minutes
records.heading: Next steps
records.content: - Configure Webhook authentication to secure your endpoint - Understand the execution model to learn how workflows process data - Webhook node reference for all available parameters
records.description: Create a webhook-triggered workflow that receives HTTP requests and sends Slack notifications. No coding required.

records.title: Configure Webhook trigger authentication in
records.heading: Prerequisites
records.content: - A workflow with a Webhook trigger node. See Build your first workflow if you need one. - The Webhook node must be in Listening state (Test or Production mode).
records.description: Set up HMAC signature verification, basic auth, or header-based authentication for Webhook trigger nodes to secure incoming requests.

records.title: Configure Webhook trigger authentication in
records.heading: Option 1: Header-based authentication
records.content: Header authentication checks for a specific key-value pair in the request headers. This is the simplest approach and works with most webhook senders. 1. Open the Webhook node settings. 1. Set Authentication to Header Auth. 1. Create a Header Auth credential with:    - Name: X-API-Key (or any custom header name)    - Value: a strong random string (minimum 32 characters) 1. Save the workflow. Requests without the correct header receive a 403 Forbidden response.
records.description: Set up HMAC signature verification, basic auth, or header-based authentication for Webhook trigger nodes to secure incoming requests.

records.title: Configure Webhook trigger authentication in
records.heading: Authenticated request
records.content: curl -X POST <https://your-instance.the> product.cloud/webhook/abc123 \  -H "X-API-Key: your-secret-value" \  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \  -d '{"event": "order.created"}'
records.description: Set up HMAC signature verification, basic auth, or header-based authentication for Webhook trigger nodes to secure incoming requests.

records.title: Configure Webhook trigger authentication in
records.heading: Option 2: Basic authentication
records.content: Basic authentication uses a username and password encoded in the Authorization header. Use this when the sending service supports HTTP Basic Auth. 1. Open the Webhook node settings. 1. Set Authentication to Basic Auth. 1. Create a Basic Auth credential with a username and password. 1. Save the workflow.
records.description: Set up HMAC signature verification, basic auth, or header-based authentication for Webhook trigger nodes to secure incoming requests.

records.title: Configure Webhook trigger authentication in
records.heading: Option 3: HMAC signature verification
records.content: HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) verification is the most secure option. The sending service signs each request body with a shared secret, and verifies the signature matches. Services like GitHub, Stripe, and Shopify use HMAC webhooks. !!! warning "version requirement"  HMAC verification in the Webhook node requires version 1.40.0 or later. For earlier versions, use a Code node after the Webhook to verify manually. 1. Open the Webhook node settings. 1. Set Authentication to None (HMAC is verified in a subsequent node). 1. Add a Code node after the Webhook node with the following JavaScript: const crypto = require('crypto'); const secret = 'your-shared-secret'; const signature = $input.first().headers['x-hub-signature-256']; const body = JSON.stringify($input.first().json); const expected = 'sha256=' + crypto  .createHmac('sha256', secret)  .update(body)  .digest('hex'); if (signature !== expected) {  throw new Error('Invalid HMAC signature'); } return $input.all(); 1. Conn
records.description: Set up HMAC signature verification, basic auth, or header-based authentication for Webhook trigger nodes to secure incoming requests.

records.title: Configure Webhook trigger authentication in
records.heading: Which method to choose
records.content: | Method | Security level | Best for | | -------- | --------------- | ---------- | | Header Auth | Medium | Internal services, simple integrations | | Basic Auth | Medium | Services that support HTTP Basic Auth | | HMAC | High | GitHub, Stripe, Shopify, any service that signs requests |
records.description: Set up HMAC signature verification, basic auth, or header-based authentication for Webhook trigger nodes to secure incoming requests.

records.title: Documentation Pipeline Demo

records.content: This is a prototype documentation site demonstrating an automated documentation pipeline with GEO (Generative Engine Optimization), faceted search via Algolia, and CI/CD quality gates.
records.description: Automated documentation pipeline with GEO optimization, faceted search, and CI/CD quality gates for workflow automation platform.

records.title: Documentation Pipeline Demo
records.heading: What this demo shows
records.content: This site is not a replacement for official docs. It demonstrates documentation infrastructure: how to organize, validate, and publish developer docs at scale using automation. The pipeline includes automated style checking with Vale, frontmatter validation for consistent metadata, GEO linting that optimizes content for AI-powered search engines, faceted search through Algolia DocSearch, and CI/CD workflows that monitor the upstream repository for documentation gaps.
records.description: Automated documentation pipeline with GEO optimization, faceted search, and CI/CD quality gates for workflow automation platform.

records.title: Reference Documentation
records.heading: Reference
records.content: Precise technical details. No tutorials — parameters, types, and defaults.
records.description: Complete reference for nodes, parameters, environment variables, CLI commands, and REST API endpoints.

records.title: Webhook node reference for
records.heading: Webhook node reference
records.content: The Webhook node is a trigger node that starts a workflow when it receives an HTTP request at a unique URL. It supports GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, and HEAD methods.
records.description: Complete parameter reference for the Webhook trigger node including HTTP methods, authentication, response modes, and binary data handling.

records.title: Webhook node reference for
records.heading: Parameters
records.content: | Parameter | Type | Default | Description | |-----------|------|---------|-------------| | HTTP Method | enum | GET | HTTP method the webhook responds to. Options: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD | | Path | string | auto-generated UUID | URL path segment. The full URL is {base_url}/webhook/{path} | | Authentication | enum | None | Authentication method. Options: None, Basic Auth, Header Auth | | Respond | enum | When Last Node Finishes | When to send the HTTP response. Options: Immediately, When Last Node Finishes, Using Respond to Webhook Node | | Response Code | number | 200 | HTTP status code returned to the caller | | Response Data | enum | First Entry JSON | What data to return. Options: All Entries, First Entry JSON, First Entry Binary, No Response Body |
records.description: Complete parameter reference for the Webhook trigger node including HTTP methods, authentication, response modes, and binary data handling.

records.title: Webhook node reference for
records.heading: Authentication options
records.content: | Method | Credential type | Header checked | |--------|----------------|----------------| | None | — | — | | Basic Auth | Basic Auth | Authorization: Basic {base64} | | Header Auth | Header Auth | Custom header name/value pair |
records.description: Complete parameter reference for the Webhook trigger node including HTTP methods, authentication, response modes, and binary data handling.

records.title: Webhook node reference for
records.heading: URLs
records.content: Each Webhook node generates two URLs: - Test URL: Active only while the workflow editor is open and listening. Format: {base_url}/webhook-test/{path} - Production URL: Active when the workflow is toggled to Active. Format: {base_url}/webhook/{path} === "Cloud"  Base URL: <https://your-instance.app.the> product.cloud === "Self-hosted"  Base URL: your configured WEBHOOK_URL environment variable, or <http://localhost:5678> by default.
records.description: Complete parameter reference for the Webhook trigger node including HTTP methods, authentication, response modes, and binary data handling.

records.title: Webhook node reference for
records.heading: Output
records.content: The Webhook node outputs a single item with the following structure: {  "json": {  "headers": { "content-type": "application/json", "...": "..." },  "params": {},  "query": { "key": "value" },  "body": { "...": "request body..." }  } } For binary data (file uploads), the node outputs an additional binary key.
records.description: Complete parameter reference for the Webhook trigger node including HTTP methods, authentication, response modes, and binary data handling.

records.title: Webhook node reference for
records.heading: Environment variables
records.content: | Variable | Default | Description | |----------|---------|-------------| | WEBHOOK_URL | <http://localhost:5678> | Base URL for webhook endpoints | | APP_PAYLOAD_SIZE_MAX | 16 | Maximum request body size in MB |
records.description: Complete parameter reference for the Webhook trigger node including HTTP methods, authentication, response modes, and binary data handling.

records.title: Troubleshooting Guide
records.heading: Troubleshooting
records.content: Problem → cause → solution. Start here when something breaks.
records.description: Solutions for common problems including webhook failures, credential errors, execution timeouts, and memory issues.

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.heading: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.content: The Webhook node does not respond to incoming HTTP requests. The sender receives a timeout, connection refused, or 404 error.
records.description: Troubleshoot Webhook nodes that do not receive requests. Common causes include inactive workflows, wrong URL type, and network configuration.

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.heading: Cause 1: Using Test URL with an inactive editor
records.content: Symptom: Requests to the Test URL return a timeout or 404 after you close the editor tab. Why: The Test URL (/webhook-test/...) is only active while the workflow editor is open and the workflow is in Listening mode. Closing the browser tab deactivates it. Fix: Toggle the workflow to Active and use the Production URL (/webhook/...) instead. The Production URL remains active as long as the workflow is enabled.
records.description: Troubleshoot Webhook nodes that do not receive requests. Common causes include inactive workflows, wrong URL type, and network configuration.

hierarchy.lvl2: Cause 1: Using Test URL with an inactive editor

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.heading: Cause 2: Workflow not activated
records.content: Symptom: Requests to the Production URL return 404 Not Found. Why: The Production URL only works when the workflow toggle is set to Active (green). An inactive workflow does not register its webhook endpoints. Fix: Open the workflow in the editor. Toggle the Active switch in the top-right corner. Verify the Production URL returns a response.
records.description: Troubleshoot Webhook nodes that do not receive requests. Common causes include inactive workflows, wrong URL type, and network configuration.

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.heading: Cause 3: Firewall or reverse proxy blocking requests
records.content: Symptom: Requests from external services timeout. Local curl requests work fine. Why: listens on port 5678 by default. If your server firewall or reverse proxy (Nginx, Caddy, Traefik) does not forward traffic to this port, external requests never reach. Fix: === "Docker with Nginx"  Verify your Nginx config forwards to the container:  ``nginx  location /webhook/ {  proxy_pass <http://the> product:5678;  proxy_set_header Host $host;  proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;  } === "Direct install"  Check that port 5678 is open:  ``bash  sudo ufw allow 5678  # or  sudo firewall-cmd --add-port=5678/tcp --permanent
records.description: Troubleshoot Webhook nodes that do not receive requests. Common causes include inactive workflows, wrong URL type, and network configuration.

hierarchy.lvl2: Cause 3: Firewall or reverse proxy blocking requests

code_snippets: ```nginx  location /webhook/ {  proxy_pass <http://the> product:5678;  proxy_set_header Host $host;  proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;  } === "Direct install"  Check that port 5678 is open:  ```

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.heading: Cause 4: Incorrect WEBHOOK_URL environment variable
records.content: Symptom: The Webhook node shows a URL that does not match your domain. External services cannot reach it. Why: uses the WEBHOOK_URL environment variable to generate webhook URLs. If this is set to <http://localhost:5678> (the default), external services cannot resolve localhost. Fix: Set WEBHOOK_URL to your public-facing URL: export WEBHOOK_URL=<https://the> product.yourdomain.com
records.description: Troubleshoot Webhook nodes that do not receive requests. Common causes include inactive workflows, wrong URL type, and network configuration.

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
records.heading: Still not working?
records.content: 1. Check the logs for errors: docker logs or the process output. 1. Test with a minimal curl command from the same network as. 1. Verify the HTTP method matches (the Webhook node only responds to the configured method).
records.description: Troubleshoot Webhook nodes that do not receive requests. Common causes include inactive workflows, wrong URL type, and network configuration.

records.title: Fix: Webhook trigger not firing
